clinical_study.brief_title: Primary Care Clinical Practice Elements and Improving Overweight Children's Weight Status
clinical_study.official_title: Primary Care Clinical Practice Elements and Improving Overweight Children's Weight Status

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

clinical_study.source: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to identify whether specific clinical practices—including, body-mass-index (BMI) screening, identifying weight-related conditions (such as high blood pressure), and scheduling follow-up visits to reassess progress—will improve the weight status of overweight school-age children at one-year follow-up.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of this study is to identify specific clinical practice elements in pediatric primary care that predict improvement in weight status among overweight school-age children. Pediatricians are well-suited to regularly assess and treat school-age children who are overweight. Well-child visits present an important opportunity to assess and treat overweight children. Strategies are needed to maximize the effectiveness of this opportunity. Although the American Academy of Pediatrics endorses recommendations by the United States Preventive Services Task Force that clinicians screen for overweight, assess medical/behavior risk, and use a staged treatment approach that includes frequent reassessment, it is unclear whether these practices, when used in primary care, impact whether children make lifestyle changes or improve their weight status. It is essential to identify specific clinical practice elements and communication strategies associated with weight-status improvement in overweight children, to maximize the effectiveness of primary-care weight-management interventions. The investigators hypothesize that conducting BMI screening, assessing weight-related comorbidities (including elevated blood pressure, acanthosis nigricans, and elevations in fasting blood glucose, lipids, and liver enzymes), and scheduling one or more interim visits to reassess progress (with a weight-related diagnosis among the top three diagnoses or by referring to a weight-management specialist or nutritionist) in overweight, 6-12 year-old primary care patients will predict improvement in weight status (assessed as decrease in BMI standard deviation score [BMI z-score]) at one-year follow-up.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to next well-child visit, one year later
primary_outcome.description: Children with a decrease in BMI z-score over 12-month period between two well-child visits (vs. children whose BMI z-score remained unchanged or increased)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to next well-child visit, one year later
secondary_outcome.description: To examine the impact of effective clinical practices on different categories of the magnitude of BMI z-score improvement, the investigators will assess factors that predict BMI-z-score changes of ≥0.25 and ≥0.5. This range of BMI-z-score change has been associated with cardiovascular-disease risk-factor improvement.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to next well-child visit, one year later
secondary_outcome.description: To examine the impact of effective clinical practices on different categories of the magnitude of BMI z-score improvement, the investigators will assess factors that predict BMI-z-score changes of ≥0.25 and ≥0.5. This range of BMI-z-score change has been associated with cardiovascular-disease risk-factor improvement.

arm_group.description: Cases, termed, "weight-status improved," are defined as children with a decrease in BMI z-score over 12-months between the first and last recorded visits that have valid height and weight data. The investigators also will stratify BMI z-score improvement by tertiles and changes in BMI z-score of ≥0.25 and ≥0.5.
Controls are defined as children whose BMI z-score remained unchanged or increased.

intervention.description: Provider identified and interpreted BMI percentile.

intervention.intervention_name: Provider addressed weight and weight-related disease risk
intervention.description: Provider addressed high weight status, including completing assessment of weight-related disease risk (indicated labs completed)
Provider and patient completed one or more interim visits to reassess progress or patient completed referral to nutrition, weight-management program, or relevant specialist

There is no indication that the provider assessed the child as overweight, including evidence of addressing weight, weight-related disease risk, scheduling an interim visit to readdress weight management

study_pop.textblock: Overweight 6-12 year-old children followed by pediatricians at community-based and academic primary-care clinics. A random sample of controls will be matched to cases by age, gender, race/ethnicity, BMI-percentile category, and clinic site.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 6-12 year-old children with ≥2 visits
- valid height and weight data at each visit
- BMI ≥85th percentile at the first visit
Exclusion Criteria:
- children <6 and >12 years old
- no valid height and weight data at two visits
- BMI <85th percentile at all 6-12 year-old well child visits
